nodes.text: Aggregate production efficiency (equal marginal rates of transformation across public and private production) is desirable in a wide variety of circumstances when taxes are set optimally
Context: combine taxation, public investment, and welfare economics to study social welfare maximization using both taxes and public production as control variables
Method: express social welfare as an indirect function of consumer prices q and choose prices q to maximize V(q) subject to production feasibility X(q) in production set G (price-based formulation)

Assumptions for main analysis: private production has constant returns to scale and competitive firms (implying zero profits), government can set commodity taxes, consumer and producer prices may differ by taxes, Walras law holds
Conclusion: At an interior optimum with positive social cost of resources, marginal rates of transformation must be equal in public and private production, implying aggregate production efficiency

Result (algebraic evidence): Lagrangian first-order conditions yield condition X*(fk - gk)=0 (equation 20), so with nonzero multiplier X marginal rates of transformation in public and private production are equal

Claim about optimal tax structure: first-order conditions relate consumer and producer prices (equations 19,21) and, for individualistic welfare, imply a constant proportionality across commodities of marginal tax revenue to commodity quantity (Ramsey-type condition, equation 23)

One-consumer geometric analysis: offer curve and production frontier intersection determines optimal decentralized outcome; optimum lies on production frontier when attainable by market prices without lump-sum transfers

Extension to many consumers: representing welfare as V(q)=U(x1(q),..., xH(q)) preserves price-based formulation and, given mild conditions (e.g., possibility of poll subsidy or continuity), implies aggregate production efficiency still desirable

Existence results: under standard continuity, convexity and boundedness assumptions on consumption sets and production set G, an attainable optimum exists (Theorems 1-3) making the maximization problem well-defined

Limitation / Counterexample: examples show optimal production can lie in interior (not weakly efficient) in special cases (e.g., particular social preferences or multihousehold configurations), so efficiency is not automatic without assumptions

Implication: when private production sectors are treated collectively, intermediate good taxes are undesirable because they prevent aggregate production efficiency and revenue could be raised equivalently by final-good taxation

Implication for untaxable sectors: if some transactions cannot be taxed, include those activities within the consumer sector representation and apply efficiency results to the remaining taxable production sectors

Extension to international trade: treating foreigners as additional consumers (if their reactions are well-defined) makes foreign trade another transformation possibility; optimal policy equates marginal transformations and taxes final sales to consumers equivalently to domestic taxes

Extension: migration and tourists can be incorporated by modeling a continuum of consumers to restore continuity of aggregate demand; migration changes derivatives and hence alters optimal tax formulas though efficiency result still expected to hold

Extensions and robustness: consumption externalities and consumer capital market imperfections alter demand responses and the optimal tax formulas (e.g., different marginal utilities of income over time), but the basic desirability of aggregate production efficiency remains under analogous conditions
